headline: Great company with great values
pros: Culture, people, access to leadership
cons: Compensation was on lower spectrum of market

headline: Great place to work, great people
pros: Accessible leadership; Strong intellectual; Great culture and team
cons: Pay below market; bonuses erratic

headline: Great place to work and build a career
pros: A family atmosphere that fosters internal promotions.
cons: There really aren't any to speak of.

headline: Don't do it.
pros: 8-5 job, alright benefits, get holidays off
cons: Management has double standards and turns a blind eye to some employees and harps on others. Hostile work enviorment

headline: Horrible place to be
pros: None that I can think of
cons: Incompetence across almost all levels

headline: Meh
pros: It was a financial Services firm
cons: Pretty much everything was horrible

headline: Wunderlich Great Company
pros: Generous payout structure for advisors
cons: 401k match could be more generous

headline: Registered Sales Assistant
pros: Can’t think of anything positive
cons: They treat their employees like absolute garbage.  The manager  has all the people skills of a blood sucking mosquito. Nasty, passive aggressive,non-comminicative. HR is totally and completely useless.  They’re all so far up each other’s rear ends they can see tonsils. No one acts as the liaison between management and employees

headline: Senior Vice President
pros: Freedom to produce, great payout, beautiful offices and friendly and cooperative fellow professionals.
cons: Company name recognition and product inventory.

headline: Associate
pros:
- Great culture, the company is invested in its junior employees

- Senior engagement and exposure to quality transactions, junior employees are given considerable autonomy and take on significant responsibility early on
cons: - Work on building up brand image

headline: Financial advisor
pros: Good work environment. Good people to work with.
cons: Low compensation percentage for commissions.

headline: Working Wonders @ Wunderlich!
pros: In my 3+ decades in the investment field, this firm is the first I have seen that does, in reality, care about helping the Financial Advisor help the client. Every decision that is made is with that in mind. It is truly refreshing and, I believe, a model for the firm of the future.
cons: Helping people learn how to spell the name can be a bit of a challenge from time to time! But then, UBS clients still think they have accounts with "USB" or "UPS!" Not a big deal.

headline: Wunderlich
pros: i cannot put 20 words together to satisfy the minimum to talk about a "pro" of working at Wunderlich Securities
cons: Management is horrible and lacks the ability to think strategically.  The salary and benefits are poor.

headline: Analyst
pros: Phenomenal experience, great managing directors, culture is awesome, senior members care about junior staff, and the firm si growing
cons: The hours are pretty long but that is as expected with the industry. Also, the firm has a lot going on currently likely contributing to the hours.

headline: Horrible
pros: There are no pros about working here
cons: Extremely poor / rude management, compensation is way below market, very high turnover

headline: Very disorganized organization.
pros: There's nothing that stands out as a pro but I had to write something.
cons: Poor management that starts from at the top.  Disorganized organization.

headline: Review
pros: work life balance is better than most firms
cons: no career growth in foreseeable future

headline: Good for career growth
pros: Flexibility (with my own supervisor)
cons: Management do not know what they are doing

headline: Must be self starter and do a lot yourself
pros:
People will help you out and work together IF you ask.
If you have a book a business there is little possibility for account overlap
cons:
You are hunting for your own bonds and there is no inventory
With no inventory if your clients are talking to a lot of players you probably won't win on price.

headline: Associate
pros: People are friendly and easy going.
cons: Compensation is lower than industry means and environment is extremely slow paced.
